I was a little overly enthusiastic about the count for the King Hidato count on a 3x3 grid. After eliminating all of the rotations, reflections, etc., I think there are only 50 unique Hamiltonian paths.

So the counts for a 3x3 graph are 3 for RooKing (vertical and horizontal moves only), 25 for Beehive (hexagonal, or square allowing diagonal moves in one direction only), and 50 for King Hidato (square allowing diagonal moves in both directions.

Update on enumerating unique paths for different types of Hidato puzzles. After seeing the images in Gyora's posting yesterday, I realized I had overlooked one simple hexagonal graph - the three-by-three arrangement of hexagons in rows of 1-2-3-2-1. As Gyora said, this is equivalent to adding the diagonals in one direction only to the square RooKing Hidato.

We've already discussed the fact that there are only three unique Hamiltonian paths (after eliminating rotations, reflections and reversals) on the 3x3 square grid with vertical and horizontal moves only. I've come up with 25 unique paths (and I think I have them all) on the corresponding hexagonal graph. I'm working on counting all of the unique paths on the 3x3 King Hidato grid, with diagonal moves in both directions. I have some way to go yet, but I am already certain the count is going to be over 100, perhaps even over 200.

Something very important is happening in this dialogue.  Woody and Mia and Dylan and Moses are standing in for many many American families in which alleged (and admitted) sexual abuse has occurred.  The Farrows and Allens are working this out, and we all as a nation are working this out at the same time, for ourselves and our own families, for our friends and relatives who have struggled and suffered.  We are wrestling again with how to support, what it means to be loyal, the role of truth and justice in family relationships.  So many people have so much invested in THIS story because it is such an American (and human) story about love, responsibility, protection, (alleged) sexual abuse, power, gender, privilege, anger, guilt. . . It is a huge accomplishment that we are talking about these subjects which have been so deeply mired in silence.  And it is riveting, because it mirrors and matches so many of our stories, our pain, confusion, anger, and conflicted love.

It is disturbing to watch this tragic situation being discussed by everyone with a seemingly fervent exuberance. There is nothing wrong with having passionate feelings. But they are just that, feelings. This horrific family story has resurfaced because of a magazine article and subsequent tweets. These writings were then followed by a commentary, then a responsive commentary and finally, this commentary today. This does not even include the voluminous number of editorial pieces penned by a more peripheral group of opinion makers. The only point that I find pertinent - the only words that I think have credence - are those whose sole message is that this prosaic circus is a terribly harmful thing - that not a single person is accomplishing anything meaningful let alone effectuating positive change. Every individual who has weighed in on this matter is allowing the court of public opinion to proliferate exponentially. When it comes to such an incredibly serious matter, to take an opinion and equate it to fact does not do justice to anyone directly involved in this case, not to those who have been sexually abused, and not to those who have been accused of sexually abusing.  I purposely have not touched this subject like so many others because I would never want the public to be my judge, jury, and executioner nor do I want that for Mr. Allen or Ms. Farrow. But again, this is just my humble opinion. So too, it will not have any impact on this matter as it should not.

The fact is that the accusation was made, and Farrow and Allen are public figures. My opinion? I just don't know, and never will, which one of these celebrities is lying...or both are. Repeat: I never will know with certainty. Neither will you.

I just don't understand readers' inability to comprehend a comment out of context and assign that meaning.  If a breakup is unbearably painful with ludicrous and ridiculous comments and behaviors, I can easily see how that kind of context would have someone "not give a second thought" to further ridiculous accusations.  Woody Allen is clearly using that way of speaking as a way of expressing his mindset at the time.  One more ridiculously slanderous assertion meant to hurt or damage him, a healthy psychological mind would likely "not give a second thought" to that kind of accusation.  Wouldn't that comment be indicative of someone who knew it to be a falsehood, and wouldn't the converse also be true (that is, if it were true, wouldn't he be panicked and immediately respond in some way).  Instead, it's completely consistent with reality, which is often messy....whether we like it or not!

Although this is eloquently written and makes many technically right points, the first sentence rings horribly, horribly false-- "...I found the idea so ludicrous I didn't give it a second thought." That is impossible. Impossible. If I were falsely accused of sexually molesting my beloved child, I would be going out of my mind with anxiety and anger and sick with concern over what this was doing to my child. Quite a bizarre claim to say he didn't give it a second thought. It renders everything else in the response, however convincingly stated, suspect.
At the same time, I don't find everything Ms. Farrow says to be credible either. The situation was clearly complicated prior to Allen's affair with Soon-Yi if Ronan is Sinatra's son, and Farrow stated it's possible. I think there is tragic behavior to ascribe to both of them in terms of how their choices may have affected the lives of their children. I hope all their children can live adult lives which are as free as possible from the fallout of their parents' narcissism.

My oh my...enough is enough as we are finally spared the tired minutiae of defensive delusions (that is, if he really does believe his tired tale). I do believe that baseball has piled up on him, of which he's exasperated a very messy situation that most of the other culprits (except Braun) avoided. Where to now....will there be anything or anyone left for poor Alex?

As a former assistant states attorney who spent several years prosecuting child molestation cases I can tell you that it is very difficult to obtain a conviction. Without physical evidence and a prompt outcry most cases are summarily dismissed or never charged. Prosecutors try to obtain confessions but without them the odds of winning are low. Certainly Woody Allen would have the upper hand in convincing a tribunal of his innocence. He is brilliant after all. But, a decision not to charge is not an acquittal. And even an acquittal does not necessarily settle the argument. I once convicted a father of molesting his 4 year old daughter. The little girl took the stand and told a jury how her "daddy used to make it rain in her bed." She was describing in child's terms her father's climax. Years later, she wrote me a letter thanking me. She wrote about how her older brother had come forward when he was 18, drug addicted, lost, in trouble with the law, to explain to his sister that he had been molested too. He felt responsible for letting it happen to her. I cannot tell you how many children slip through the system. I have interviewed so many child molesters who could look me in the eye and deny their crimes without a hint of remorse. I have spoken to priests who could deny their sins without batting an eye. Woody Allen is a genius. He may in fact be innocent. We will never know. But, I recognize something in him that has nothing to do with his fame.

So.. it is ok for Dylan and her Mother to cite the gross betrayal of trust as being pertinent - it obviously is - and yet Allen's citing of Mia Farrows self acknowledged betrayal of the son that he had been lead to believe was always his - somehow is not?

How do you think it feels for a father to find out publicly that kind of disclosure? Is it only Dylan Farrow's feelings that are to be privileged here? And isn't it germane in terms of what it continues to reveal about Mia Farrow's state of mind, her motivation and her character?

Roger:

Unfortunately, it's not just Fox News. Fox actively lies and distorts, but most of our other news media (including, unfortunately, The New York Times) are guilty of trying to promote "false equivalencies".

For every story of Republican endlessly, obviously lying, there must be a balancing tale of Democratic error. Look at the "You'll get to keep your insurance" meme. What President Obama should have said was "You'll get to keep your insurance, assuming it's not a lousy fraud that ought to be illegal that provides you with no meaningful coverage while happily taking your premiums every year." But President Obama's original statement was cast as "The lie of the year" (you've seen this quote in ads) while Republicans, lying about everything from "Death Panels" to Medicaid Expansion to even the source of the idea for the PPACA, are presented as having equivalently distorted the truth.

Another way the media, as a whole, fails to serve us daily is that they are unwilling to call a falsehood a falsehood, even when the proof is visible to everyone paying attention. When was the last time you saw (e.g.) The New York Times actually state that a Republican was lying when (e.g.) they raised the claim that president Obama was born outside of the country? By now, that's not an "error", it's a bald-faced lie and should be called such.

The problem is a lot bigger than just Rupert Murdoch's media holdings.

The Republican use of the media distorts the facts and is unprincipled. Simply put, the Republicans play dirty pool repeatedly.

Unfortunately, the media is complicit in this game by simply reporting the distortions without fact checking and challenge. We are not been served well by the media--especially the press-- when blatant inaccuracies are allowed to stand without correction.
That does not mean that they will.  Just because you can does not mean you should.

Woody Allen has every right to be angry at someone who makes the kind of allegations Mia Farrow did if he believes they are false. How kind and patient should he be with someone he thinks not only turned his child against him and damaged her for life but tried to have him sent to prison for crimes he did not commit? If Mia Farrow did indeed coach Dylan Farrow to say things that are not true, she is a monster who should be in prison herself.

Moreover, given Mia Farrow's role in breaking up Andre Previn's marriage when she was the same age as Soon Yi Previn was when she started her affair with Woody Allen, and her recently admitted adultery with Frank Sinatra, who was also married—as if THAT is something to feel proud of—exactly how civil do you expect Mr Allen to be? Especially after being defrauded of child support payments? As for Ronan, his nasty (though funny!) tweets make it perfectly fair for Mr Allen to hit back.
Considering what they have put him through, I don't blame him one little bit for wanting a soupcon of payback.

Mr. Allen should at the least have employed a good editor here, to remove his unfiltered antagonism towards Mia Farrow and especially, to Ronan, singled out for a little nasty sidebar - for - well, because Mr Allen is angry at his mother.
